importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Dina Boluarte was removed from office by Congress on this date after impeachment proceedings cited her inability to address rising crime and corruption, leading to a power vacuum and the rise of interim leadership under Jose Jeri.
The state of emergency was officially declared by Jose Jeri on this date in Lima, amid ongoing protests, marking a significant escalation in government response to public unrest and crime.

Previously, Dina Boluarte declared a 30-day state of emergency in March following the murder of singer Paul Flores, which highlighted the government's repeated attempts to address organized crime, though it failed to produce lasting results.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The state of emergency declared in Lima is set to last 30 days, beginning from October 22, 2025, and will remain in effect until November 21, 2025, during which time constitutional rights such as freedom of assembly are suspended.
Between January and September 2025, Peru reported 1,690 homicides — a rise from 1,502 in the same period of 2024 — signaling a worsening of violence linked to organized crime and extortion.

keyTakeAways: Peru’s interim president, Jose Jeri, has declared a 30-day state of emergency in the capital, Lima, following six days of uncertainty about whether the interim government would act.
The emergency allows the government to deploy the military, restrict freedom of assembly, and suspend constitutional rights, raising concerns about civil liberties.
The protests stem from widespread public anger over corruption and organized crime, particularly led by Gen-Z activists who are demanding accountability and justice.
Extortion cases have surged to 18,000 this year — a 30% increase from the previous year — and are directly linked to rising violence, including 1,690 homicides between January and September 2025.
A previous state of emergency declared by Dina Boluarte in March 2025 after the killing of singer Paul Flores failed to curb crime, indicating a pattern of ineffective policy responses.

On the day of the emergency declaration, protests turned violent, resulting in one death and around 100 injuries, including police officers and journalists, signaling the deepening crisis and public anger.
Jose Jeri, who took office after Dina Boluarte’s removal, has stated he will not resign despite mounting protests and pressure.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Peru’s interim president, Jose Jeri, has declared a 30-day state of emergency in the capital, Lima, amid sustained protests driven by youth-led movements demanding accountability for corruption and organized crime. The emergency allows the military to patrol streets and suspends constitutional rights like freedom of assembly. This comes after Dina Boluarte was removed from office in October 2025 due to her failure to address a surge in crime, including 18,000 extortion cases and 1,690 homicides between January and September 2025. The situation intensified when protests turned violent on October 22, resulting in one death and 100 injuries. Previous attempts by Boluarte to manage the crisis through emergency measures in March 2025 failed to reduce crime, indicating a recurring challenge in government response. Jeri has affirmed he will not resign despite pressure, signaling a continuation of the crisis and deepening public discontent.
title: State of emergency declared in Peru’s capital amid protests
